lead_paragraph: Even in a country with a lot of wilderness, it was a shocking death. Taylor Josephine Stephanie Luciow, a promising 19-year-old folk singer from Toronto who performed under the name Taylor Mitchell, was attacked by two coyotes as she set out for a hike in Cape Breton Highlands National Park, one of Eastern Canada’s leading tourist destinations. She died late Tuesday night in Halifax, where she had been airlifted for treatment.

Although as the law currently sits, citizen journalists and bloggers seem eligible for the same protections, some are worried about an amendment from Sen. Charles Schumer that would leave them behind. Writing in Mediashift.org, Rob Arcamona said:

abstract: A new study on how the shifts in and out of daylight saving time affect workplace injuries.
snippet: A new study on how the shifts in and out of daylight saving time affect workplace injuries.
lead_paragraph: Yesterday we gained an hour, thanks to the end of daylight saving time. I love this transition out of daylight saving time during the fall, but I hate the transition into daylight saving time during the spring, when we lose an hour. And new research shows there is good reason for this preference: people are much less likely to get hurt at work when they “fall backward” than when they “spring forward.”

headline.main: Why ‘Falling Back’ Is Better Than ‘Springing Forward’

lead_paragraph: When a coalition of investors and wind developers from the United States and China announced plans for a large-scale wind project in West Texas last week, many of our readers expressed outrage that a portion of the financing might well come from the $22 billion set aside in the economic stimulus package for clean energy projects — and green jobs.

headline.main: Of China, Texas and Green Jobs

headline.main: Who Receives Sick Leave?

abstract: The billionaire’s investments in railroads are relatively recent.

lead_paragraph: Warren E. Buffett’s investments in railroads are relatively recent. In fact, it was not until 2006 that Mr. Buffett’s holding company, Berkshire Hathaway, began building a stake in the industry. Despite the economic downturn, Mr. Buffett continued to build his position in many of the major railroads in the United States – concentrating most of his investment in Burlington Northern Santa Fe, which he agreed to acquired fully on Tuesday for $26 billion in cash and stock.

abstract: Buying a going concern seems like a common-sense approach to business ownership, yet the thought doesn’t occur to many entrepreneurs.
snippet: Buying a going concern seems like a common-sense approach to business ownership, yet the thought doesn’t occur to many entrepreneurs.
lead_paragraph: Sam was typical of many aspiring entrepreneurs. He had a paper route as a kid and worked for several companies as a young man, including J.C. Penney, where he discovered a passion for retail. After college and a stint in the armed services, he decided to pursue the path of business ownership. Rather than start a business from scratch, he borrowed $20,000 from his father-in-law, added it to $5,000 he had in savings and bought an existing franchise location, a Ben Franklin general merchandise store.

headline.main: Buying a Business Instead of Starting One

abstract: To take Synergenz’s Respiragene test, consumers swab the inside of a cheek to get DNA and send the sample to a laboratory in Kentucky. The Synergenz Web site says a physician is required to sign a form requesting the test. The Respiragene test looks at 20 spots in a person’s genome where DNA varies among people. It uses that data, as well as nongenetic information like the person’s smoking history, to compute a risk score.

abstract: The Deal Professor takes a look at the latest developments in the three-way battle of the fertilizer giants and concludes that the “forever war” may soon draw to a close.
snippet: The Deal Professor takes a look at the latest developments in the three-way battle of the fertilizer giants and concludes that the “forever war” may soon draw to a close.
lead_paragraph: The battle between CF Industries, Terra Industries and Agrium looks to be near a conclusion after the events of the past week. CF raised its hostile offer for Terra to $40.61 a share in cash and stock, an offer that was rejected about 48 hours later by Terra’s board. Meanwhile, Agrium raised its hostile offer for CF to $92.99 a share in cash and stock, an offer that was rejected less than 24 hours later by CF’s board.

headline.main: An End Game for the Forever War?

abstract: The reality of one small-business owner’s journey.
snippet: The reality of one small-business owner’s journey.
lead_paragraph: As some of you will recall, I have been following the progress of (and offering advice to) Debbie Dusenberry, the owner of a home-furnishing and gift store in Kansas called Curious Sofa. You can read “When Passion Meets Math” to see how Ms. Dusenberry built her store, garnered lots of media attention for her merchandising, ran smack into the Great Recession and began the journey from artist to businesswoman. This small-business journey is far more common than most people understand. Ms. Dusenberry is so good at the artistry that she is envied by other owners, one of whom has called her “retail royalty.” But as you will see in a moment, her retail reality is very different.

headline.main: The Dusenberry Diary: Living the Dream? Or Just Living?

The repeal of the Glass-Steagall Act of 1933 was seen at the time as a way to help American banks grow larger and better compete on the world stage.

abstract: Amaranth Advisors, the hedge fund that closed its doors three years ago after losing more than $6.6 billion on wrong-way bets on the price of natural gas, said on Monday that it has dropped its lawsuit against hedge fund manager Paul Touradji and his firm, Touradji Capital Management.
snippet: Amaranth Advisors, the hedge fund that closed its doors three years ago after losing more than $6.6 billion on wrong-way bets on the price of natural gas, said on Monday that it has dropped its lawsuit against hedge fund manager Paul Touradji and ...
lead_paragraph: Amaranth Advisors, the hedge fund that closed its doors three years ago after losing more than $6.6 billion on wrong-way bets on the price of natural gas, said on Monday that it had dropped its two-month old lawsuit against the hedge fund manager Paul Touradji and his firm, Touradji Capital Management. The suit claimed that Mr. Touradji breached two separate contracts signed in September 2006 that governed the transfer and purchase of Amaranth’s base metals portfolio. Mr. Touradji and his firm were accused of using confidential information about Amaranth’s trading strategy and its positions to unjustly profit. Touradji Capital denied Amaranth’s allegations, saying that its conduct in assuming the risk of Amaranth’s base metal portfolio was professional and lawful. “Amaranth has received and evaluated additional information regarding the transaction, including trading records and other information voluntarily provided by Touradji Capital, that is consistent with Touradji Capital’s position that it did not violate the agreement with Amaranth and did not misuse Amaranth’s proprietary information,” Amaranth said in a statement. “Accordingly, Amaranth has withdrawn its summons and notice and elected not to serve a complaint against Touradji Capital.” “Amaranth’s decision to withdraw its claims vindicates our position that we acted appropriately and with the utmost of professionalism,” Mr. Touradji said in a statement. “It also clearly validates our previous statement that the Amaranth suit was based on the misinformation of two disgruntled former employees involved in separate litigation with T.C.M.” The two former employees are Robert Vollero and Gentry Beach. The men sued Touradji Capital last December, contending that they were owed $50 million in unpaid bonuses. The hedge fund filed a countersuit against the men this month alleging that the two men had lied about their abilities, stole company secrets and defamed the firm. Touradji Capital is seeking more than $250 million as compensation for financial and reputational damage

headline.main: Amaranth Withdraws Lawsuit Against Touradji Capital

abstract: When is a good deal not a good deal?
snippet: When is a good deal not a good deal?
lead_paragraph: In a column in The New York Times on Sunday, Richard Thaler explored what he called the diabolical economics of Swoopo, an online auction site. Swoopo sells merchandise, typically for below its price elsewhere, but charges 60 cents for every bid. lead_paragraph: On the 21st day (of October) President Obama said, “Let there be a conference.” And so there was. This morning, small-business owners, their representatives, their lenders, and their lenders’ representatives — some 70 people in all — gathered in the gilded and marble-clad Cash Room of the United States Treasury. The venue was appropriate, since, after all, the whole point of the exercise was to figure out how to get more capital in the hands of small business.

headline.main: Talking the Talk in the Cash Room

lead_paragraph: Lani Hay, daughter of Vietnamese immigrants, retired from the Navy as an intelligence officer, and then with her American Express card and some savings, opened a technology consulting business serving the federal government. By 2007, just four years after it opened its doors, Lanmark Technology had grown to bring in $12 million in annual revenue and employ 100 people.* Then the recession hit. “Along with L.M.T.’s annual revenues dropping, L.M.T.’s line of credit was also dropped, by a bank that bought out the bank that I was working with,” Ms. Hay said Wednesday in a conference in Washington, convened by the Obama administration to address the problems small businesses have had finding capital during the recession. Worse, she said, the bank canceled the credit line just before she was to receive a $500,000 contract from the Defense Department — and she had needed the credit to tide her firm over until the government paid its bills.

headline.main: In the Cash Room, the Obama Administration Is All Ears

abstract: Here’s the crux of the problem: If you own a business that has zero debt, you have an artificial situation. Let’s do the math.
snippet: Here’s the crux of the problem: If you own a business that has zero debt, you have an artificial situation. Let’s do the math.
lead_paragraph: I hate making analogies between selling a business and selling a house. It offends me on many levels, but nevertheless, here I go. I was watching an episode of “The Property Ladder” on the Learning Channel, and it got me thinking about preparing for sale. I watched home owners spend months filled with 16-hour days of hard labor, ripping out walls, installing cabinets and laying tile. Every decision — from paint color to countertops to flooring — was made with a buyer and an asking price in mind.

headline.main: Trying to Sell Your Business? Think Like a Buyer

abstract: Some advice from those with firsthand experience of divorce may help you avoid the financial pitfalls of a split.

lead_paragraph: Nobody can relate to the raw, visceral experience of ending a marriage better than someone who has gone through it. abstract: United Parcel Service will increase ground-shipment rates in 2010 by 4.9 percent, less than this year, as volume drops.
snippet: United Parcel Service will increase ground-shipment rates in 2010 by 4.9 percent, less than this year, as volume drops.
lead_paragraph: United Parcel Service will increase ground-shipment rates in 2010 by 4.9 percent, less than this year, as volume drops. Average rates for goods sent by air will rise 6.9 percent, with a two percentage point cut in the fuel surcharge on those deliveries, the same as this year, U.P.S. said Friday. Fuel charges during 2010 also will be adjusted more slowly once the changes take effect on Jan. 4, U.P.S. said. The rate increase for U.P.S.’s ground unit is smaller than 5.9 percent increase in 2009, which was the most in at least eight years as the company faced higher costs for labor, health care and pensions. U.P.S.’s domestic business has contracted for seven consecutive quarters as the recession damped demand.

He was so busy running his company, he didn’t notice the moles that had started to look different. My friend is only 38 years old.

abstract: Some contestants of NBC’s “The Biggest Loser” say that dangerous weight-loss techniques are common.

lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES  When more than 40 former contestants from “The Biggest Loser” gather Wednesday for a reunion television special, the winner of the program’s first season, Ryan C. Benson, who lost 122 of his 330-pound starting weight, will be absent. Mr. Benson is now back above 300 pounds but he thinks he has been shunned by the show because he publicly admitted that he dropped some of the weight by fasting and dehydrating himself to the point that he was urinating blood.

headline.main: On ‘The Biggest Loser,’ Health Can Take Back Seat

abstract: Allan E. Parrish asks us where pitchers are often put.
snippet: Allan E. Parrish asks us where pitchers are often put.
lead_paragraph: WEDNESDAY’S PUZZLE — There was a recent discussion among some crossword constructors about how to clue the word NURSE. Past descriptions have included “Surgeon’s assistant” or “M*A*S*H extra.” The former clue seems to relegate the nurse to a mere supporting role. The latter is particularly troublesome because in both the movie and the TV show, some of the main characters were nurses and extras could be found with any job description. The implication was that all this was borderline demeaning to a noble profession and perhaps even sexist. (Constructors are overwhelmingly male. Solvers, as far as I can tell, split more or less evenly.)

headline.main: M*A*S*H Extra

abstract: Citigroup agreed to sell a credit card unit, Diners Club North America, to Bank of Montreal for an undisclosed price.
snippet: Citigroup agreed to sell a credit card unit, Diners Club North America, to Bank of Montreal for an undisclosed price.
lead_paragraph: Citigroup agreed to sell a credit card unit, Diners Club North America, to Bank of Montreal for an undisclosed price, ending its 28-year-old ties to the world’s first charge card. The sale will reduce Citigroup’s assets by about $1 billion, representing about 0.05 percent of the lender’s total global assets of $1.89 trillion. The deal will not have a material impact on Citigroup’s net income or capital ratios, the bank said. Bank of Montreal said in a separate statement that the acquisition would more than double its business in corporate credit cards, adding $7.8 billion in card transactions and net receivables of $1 billion.

headline.main: Canada: Bank of Montreal Buys Diners Club
headline.print_headline: CANADA: BANK OF MONTREAL BUYS DINERS CLUB

abstract: Managers and insiders who orchestrated an extensive fraud at the Indian outsourcing company Satyam Computer Services bought more than 1,000 pieces of property with the money they diverted.
snippet: Managers and insiders who orchestrated an extensive fraud at the Indian outsourcing company Satyam Computer Services bought more than 1,000 pieces of property with the money they diverted.
lead_paragraph: Managers and insiders who orchestrated an extensive fraud at the Indian outsourcing company Satyam Computer Services bought more than 1,000 pieces of property with the money they diverted, the Central Bureau of Investigation in India said. The bureau also said the 10 people accused in the case had forged board resolutions, obtained unauthorized loans and created more fake customers and generated more fake invoices than previously discovered. Satyam’s founder admitted in January to faking $1 billion in cash on the company’s balance sheet.

headline.main: India: Satyam Managers in Fraud Bought Property
headline.print_headline: INDIA: SATYAM MANAGERS IN FRAUD BOUGHT PROPERTY

abstract: A government ministry in Vietnam is starting a pilot project to revive the export of puffer fish after a ban of six years.
snippet: A government ministry in Vietnam is starting a pilot project to revive the export of puffer fish after a ban of six years.
lead_paragraph: A government ministry in Vietnam is starting a pilot project to revive the export of puffer fish, known for its toxic skin and internal organs, after a ban of six years, according to The Vietnam News, an official newspaper in English. The goal of the project is to produce 800 to 1,000 tons of products worth up to $10 million by the end of 2012. In 2003, the government prohibited the processing, trade and use of puffer fish because of a high number of poisoning cases.

headline.main: Vietnam: Export of Puffer Fish Is Approved

In his debut puzzle, a Monday I also enjoyed (Across Lite, Solution), he billed himself as Edward M. Sessa. By puzzle No. 2 he was down to Edward Sessa, and today he’s a mere Ed Sessa. Letters are starting to get critical at this point, so who knows what he’ll be next. In any case, you now have links to all his puzzles and you can solve his entire oeuvre. Desoer, would receive less in salary for 2009, citing a review by the government’s special master for compensation, Kenneth R. Feinberg. abstract: Peru formally concluded a joint free trade agreement with Switzerland, Norway, Liechtenstein and Iceland.
snippet: Peru formally concluded a joint free trade agreement with Switzerland, Norway, Liechtenstein and Iceland.
lead_paragraph: Peru formally concluded a joint free trade agreement with Switzerland, Norway, Liechtenstein and Iceland, the trade and tourism minister, Martin Perez, said Friday. The four countries make up the European Free Trade Agreement trading bloc. Peruvian exports to the block were worth $3.4 billion last year, Mr. Perez said in a statement. Imports from the bloc totaled $1.3 billion. In the first nine months of the year, Peruvian exports to those countries rose by 18 percent, compared with the same period last year, Mr. Perez said. Sectors that will benefit the most from the new agreement are fishing and industry, Mr. Perez said.

abstract: Two freelancers, who were kidnapped and held for 15 months, went to Somalia with fewer resources than their counterparts from major news organizations.
snippet: Two freelancers, who were kidnapped and held for 15 months, went to Somalia with fewer resources than their counterparts from major news organizations.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA  Amanda Lindhout was a waitress at an Irish pub in Calgary, Alberta, with a dream of becoming a journalist. But Ms. Lindhout, who has no formal journalistic training, did not join the ranks of citizen journalists who blog about their communities. Instead, she used her earnings from the bar to finance reporting trips to several of the world’s most dangerous war zones.

headline.main: For Novice Journalists, Rising Risks in Conflict Zones

abstract: Abu Dhabi’s priority is to stop a bank run, rather than undertake a wholesale rescue of Dubai World.

lead_paragraph: Abu Dhabi is preparing a pick ’n’ mix bailout of Dubai. The richest of the United Arab Emirates seems set to support its struggling neighbor, which shocked markets worldwide last week by calling for a standstill on $59 billion of debt at Dubai World, its investment arm. But helping only on a case-by-case basis sounds sensible. Abu Dhabi’s priority is to stop a bank run, rather than undertake a wholesale rescue of Dubai World.

abstract: Dubai’s debt crisis of the last few days has fed speculation that Abu Dhabi would impose conditions for any bailout, including a stake in prominent Dubai enterprises like Emirates Airlines.

lead_paragraph: It was the most subtle of gestures, but looking back, many in Dubai now see it as a sign of their salvation. At the grand opening of the Dubai Air Show this month, the crown prince of Abu Dhabi, Sheik Muhammad bin Zayed al-Nahyan, placed his hand over the hand of Dubai’s ruler, Sheik Mohammed bin Rashid al-Maktoum. That was widely viewed among people here as a sign that Abu Dhabi, by far the largest and richest member-state of the United Arab Emirates federation, would take care of Dubai.

headline.main: Will Abu Dhabi Impose Conditions for Dubai Bailout?

abstract: At some point, whether now or in a few months, business owners are going to have to switch from playing defense to playing offense.
snippet: At some point, whether now or in a few months, business owners are going to have to switch from playing defense to playing offense.
lead_paragraph: I have a friend who recently told me that, as the recession took hold, he was forced to stop all capital expenditures for his wholesale distribution company, and I mean all. He even put off spending $2,500 to replace the server that runs his entire company. He has been hit hard, and I understand why he stopped all expenditures. He had no choice. But I suggested to him that if the old server went down, it would be the most expensive $2,500 that he ever “saved.” Clearly, the damage caused would far exceed the money saved. He agreed, and he’s now setting aside cash to get a new one.

headline.main: Is It Too Early to Start Thinking About a Rebound?

abstract: After Dubai World set off turmoil in global markets, many expected reassuring words from the federal government in oil-rich Abu Dhabi. Instead, there was silence.
snippet: After Dubai World set off turmoil in global markets, many expected reassuring words from the federal government in oil-rich Abu Dhabi. Instead, there was silence.
lead_paragraph: This article was reported by Robert F. Worth, Heather Timmons and Landon Thomas Jr.  and written by Mr. Thomas.

headline.main: Speculation Grows Over a Tense Rift, With Billions at Stake
headline.print_headline: Speculation Grows Over a Tense Rift, With Billions at Stake

byline.original: By Robert F. Worth, Heather Timmons and Landon Thomas Jr

abstract: The debt crisis could be a way for Abu Dhabi to demand greater control over Dubai, and perhaps over all the members of the United Arab Emirates.
snippet: The debt crisis could be a way for Abu Dhabi to demand greater control over Dubai, and perhaps over all the members of the United Arab Emirates.
lead_paragraph: Corrected | 8:32 a.m. As the financial markets reopened in Dubai on Monday after several days of uncertainty over the emirate’s debt crisis, many were expecting a reassuring statement from the federal government in Abu Dhabi, trusting that the United Arab Emirates would be eager to stem further fears in markets around the world, The New York Times’s Robert F. Worth, Heather Timmons and Landon Thomas Jr. report.

headline.main: Abu Dhabi’s Silence Raises the Heat on Dubai

abstract: A small-business owner who travels frequently to Brazil has learned the country’s secrets and even enjoys the flight.

lead_paragraph: I’VE been flying since I was a child. I was only 8 years old when I had my first solo flight to Europe. I had to wear my passport around my neck, and I always got a lot of attention from the flight attendants. Many of them would put me in the business-class section, even though I belonged in economy.

headline.main: The Joys, and Lessons, of Traveling to Brazil

abstract: Dubai’s state-owned companies hold properties around the world that could wind up on the auction block — potentially at fire-sale prices — as the city-state aims to pay off its creditors.
snippet: Dubai’s state-owned companies hold properties around the world that could wind up on the auction block — potentially at fire-sale prices — as the city-state aims to pay off its creditors.
lead_paragraph: Much of the billions of dollars that Dubai borrowed during the boom years went to help build grandiose trophy real estate projects at home like an indoor skiing arena, the world’s largest airport, artificial palm-shaped islands and the world’s tallest building. But the emirate’s state-owned companies also went on a spending spree abroad, acquiring properties and companies that could now wind up on the auction block — potentially at fire-sale prices — to pay off its creditors.

headline.main: Dubai Inc.’s Holdings May Go Up for Auction
